1. I live in Milford, Delaware and I immediately searched for my county upon seeing the title of this graph. I noticed that I am particularly at risk for hurricanes, which--although we've had several--doesn't seem like it would be the most significant issue in my small state. I don't believe that we get nearly enough rainfall to be considered at risk for hurricanes.
2. Secondly, I wonder what this graph would correlate with. To elaborate, would states with higher sea level risks have more people who own boats? Or would people in CA--who are at risk for wildfires--be more likely to own a fire extinguisher compared to people who live in hurricane risk areas.
3. Finally, although this is completely irrelevant to the graph, I wondered why counties are shaped the way they are. The division of people into smaller classifications than states makes little to no sense to me, and the fact that there are counties in states like Nevada that are almost four times the size of my state boggles my mind.

My county is Alameda County in California, USA. I noticed that our biggest climate threat is water stress. Water stress could mean anything, it is a vague and broad term. It could mean water scarcity, water quality, and the accessibility to water. It is possible that it is all of the above. I wonder how the water stress is being handled. Is there a plan for the restricted water access? This will impact me and my community because we need water and we use it on a daily basis. Our water could be poor quality with or without our knowledge, or we might just stop getting water all together. This graph is showing me that my community is in danger because of water stress, something everyone needs. My catchy headline would be, "Where is all of our water going?!"

The first thing I did as many Americans did, I looked at my current home state. Once I looked at my home state (North Carolina) I see that we have almost every risk, with the exception of wildfires and water stress. As someone who  lives on coastal Carolina's, hurricanes are really common, though I guess 2020 felt bad and let up a little. The north east of the state is at risk of sea levels rising. More than half of the state is prone to hurricane risk. Then the western part of the state is prone to heavy rainfall. If you look very closely, the far west of the state is prone to heat stress. To add to that if you look and go from east to west, the colors change in order which I find really interesting. The colors shift from dark green, to light green, to dark blue, to light blue, or pale orange, to full orange. This could have something to do with the way the state goes from beaches to the Appalachian mountains, but I??m no expert.

In the What??s Going On in This Graph? Oct. 21, 2020 article, the New York Times discusses the climate threat in the Unites States. This graph shows how climate change is affecting each community. For example, in Hennepin County the water stress risk and heat stress risk are medium. There is no risk of our county having hurricanes or sea level increase. Based on the graph, if the risk level is low, the color is lighter. If the risk level is very high, the color is darker. We noticed that Missouri and Illinois have the most extreme heat. We also noticed that Ohio, West Virginia, and Kentucky have the most extreme rainfall. In addition, we noticed that Alaska has the most sea level rise. We learned that water stress reflects the change in drought-like conditions. We wonder what the United States is going to do to stop climate change. We wonder why there is such extreme rainfall at the top of Minnesota.

I notice that Kuala Lumpur and San Fransisco have low rates of particulate pollution (San Fransisco usually below 25 micrograms per cubic meter, and Kuala Lumpur remaining below 50 micrograms per cubic meter) except for a brief spike when it was approximately 150 micrograms per cubic meter. New Delhi has exceptionally high levels starting at about 350 micrograms per cubic centimeter and forming a negative slope until the outliers at the end. Title: How deadly is your air?

What do you notice?
I notice that Nairobi, Kenya has the healthiest air out of the 12 major cities, and New Delhi has the unhealthiest air out of the group. San Francisco had a spike of unhealthy air in November '18, but it has gotten better through rest of the year, while Kaula Lumpur, Malaysia's air quality got worse, and then recovered towards the end of the year. The New Delhi air got better through the middle of the year, and then got juristically worst at the end of the year.
What do you wonder?
Knowing that the United States of America is the third most populated country, I wonder why the air quality of its major cities isn't worse? I also wonder what countries are doing to improve their air quality and what policies are being placed to restore clean air. 
Headline?
Not all air is not equal

Many of you have noticed which cities have high and which cities have low air pollution.  But, how about which cities has the most variability in their air pollution?  What is the cause of this variability?  Addressing this cause will lower air pollution.
  
These 12 graphs are a few from the 47 that are in the New York Times article.  By Friday, we will share the link to the article.  There, you can also input your city and learn what it??s particulate matter concentration is.

Looking at these graphs makes me wonder how they would look for December 2019 to December 2020, when much of the world shut down due to COVID-19. I suspect there would be significant drops in air pollution around the world. It is important that the world function at pre-pandemic levels, however, if the numbers for air pollution are significantly lower during 2020, it is a potent message about the impact we can have on our planet if the world works together to reduce air pollution.

user_display_name: Grace U, Kaitlin B, Evan D, Brian S
comment: Based on the data displayed on the graph, our group noticed several important observations. The first being that of the various cities, New Delhi had the highest amount of air pollution. Much of the pollution in New Delhi occurs during the winter months. The air in New Dehli often remains in the unhealthy to hazardous range. San Francisco had a large spike in November of 2018, but it has been steady since then. Kuala Lumpur also had a large spike in the middle of seemingly steady pollution rates. Based on these observations, we wonder what causes the air pollution in Beijing and New Delhi to fluctuate so much. We also wondered What caused the large spikes in Kuala Lumpur and San Francisco and how did San Francisco improve its air quality after the spike? Lastly, we analyzed what impact these findings had on ourselves and our community. Air pollution plays a major role in not only our health but also the health of the surrounding community. Furthermore, significant pollution can have harmful effects on the eco

Group 5: Macy, Grace, Lynzie, Musa
We noticed that the air is the most unhealthy in the city of New Delhi, as it is almost at the hazardous level. Nairobi, Kenya and Manhattan are the cities shown with the healthiest air. Cities like Beijing and Kampala, Uganda also have pretty unhealthy air. We wonder why the air is so bad in these huge cities with so many people living in them. We also wonder if there is anything being done at the moment to help the cities with air pollution that is hazardous. Finally, we wonder what is causing the unhealthy air in some of these cities and how the air got so bad. The impact this has on our community is that it could be dangerous for the people in these cities. Having unhealthy air could cause health issues for some people, especially if they live in one of the cities with a high amount of unhealthy air.

Group 7: Bianca, Bri, Sara W, Jocelyn
After observing the data from some major cities around the world, we noticed that American cities have healthier air compared to other cities around the world. We noticed that cities with very large and concentrated populations like New Delhi and Beijing have hazardous air. We noticed that San Francisco has a spike in late November 2018. Other than that, San Francisco seems to have the healthiest air.
	We wonder why the air pollution in  New Delhi is so high although you don??t hear about it in the news. We also wonder why bigger cities have healthier air although they still produce a lot of pollution. We wonder what could have caused the spike in poor air quality in San Francisco, could it have been wildfires? Finally, we wonder why a Megacity like Tokyo has such clean air compared to other megacities like Beijing and New Delhi. 
The impact of these statistics tells us that there could be potential hazards in the air that we breathe, even if we don??t live in a big city.

??Air Pollution: Is Your City at Risk???

Our group noticed many things in this graph, such as Nairobi and Manhattan have the best air quality out of all the cities. The size and population of the city does not determine the air quality as Los Angeles is a huge city, but has good air quality. New Delhi has the worst air quality out of all the cities. New Delhi is the only city that reaches the extreme in the air quality index. There is a key to represent the different colors on the graph. Green and yellow mean good air quality, while red and orange mean unhealthy or hazardous air quality. Our group wondered what happened in San Francisco to cause such a big spike in air pollution and why famous tourist cities like Paris or Manhattan have low pollution levels. We wondered what the X-axis represents and why a lot of cities show spikes in air quality levels. We also wondered why New Delhi has the worst air quality, is it because they have a lot of factories that pollute gases? This impacts us and our community b

Welcome to Wednesday's moderation of ??What??s Going On in This Graph???  

Today??s graphs show the daily average air pollution in a dozen major cities from around the world for the year Nov. 2018 ?C Oct. 2019.  Note that all graphs use the same scale to show the number of micrograms per cubic meter of outdoor particulate pollution.  .

From 9 am ?C 2 pm E.T. today, share with us your responses online to these three questions -- "What do you notice?",  "What do you wonder?", and ??What impact does this topic have on you and your community???

Plus, please share with us a catchy headline that captures the ideas in these graphs. 

By Friday morning, we??ll reveal the article that included these graphs and much more.  We look forward to reading your discoveries.

Note that you can get a link to your response to share with your teacher and classmates by clicking the response box below your response ??Email me when my comment is published.??  

Please visit our archive to see all graphs in this series (tinyurl.co

This article  shows eleven graphs that each reveal the amount of air pollution in different cities around the world.A key is given to understand the different colors shown on the graphs.Yellow is good while red is unhealthy,hazardous or extreme air pollution.Kenya,Manhattan,Tokyo,Los Angeles,Paris,and Sao Paulo Brazil all seem to stay between the regular air pollution levels while Mexico City,Uganda,Kuala Lumpur,Malaysia,San Francisco and Beijing all have red marks which demonstrates that air pollution is maximum in those cities.I believe this is because these cities are more occupied and there are more factories in these cities that could be there main contribution to pollution.These cities are in different countries which one can assume that pollution is a problem that is faced throughout all the world.Giving into account that this information is not current it is most likely that air pollution has risen in these cities.

What do you notice?
I notice that most of the cities stay similar. Some of the cities have spikes in air pollution like San Francisco, while in Nairobi the air pollution stays pretty steady. I also notice that New Delhi has a very high amount of air pollution. 

What do you wonder?
I wonder what happened in San Francisco to cause such a high spike in air pollution. I was thinking maybe a fire because it is in California. 

What impact does this have on you and your community?
I live in the suburbs so the air pollution isn't as high. I don??t think Boston's air pollution is nearly as high as some of the other major cities, but there's definitely air pollution. 

What??s going on in this graph? Write a catchy headline that captures the graph??s main idea.
"Is your City Affected by Air Pollution?"

This impacts our community because it might determine what's best for our future with the fewest casualties. This can impact government decisions on how the vaccine is distributed. In graph A, I noticed that the United States will reach herd immunity by July. We risk losing 100,000 people until that time. This affects me and the peers in my community because July is the heart of summer. This makes me wonder if the death toll will be higher, or lower because at that time more people will be vaccinated. Graph A is the most likely to happen if we continue to apply adequate public precautions. It represents our current pace of 1.7 million vaccines per day, and when looking at it I felt a sense of hope because I can finally see the finish line. But because the virus is unpredictable, there are other scenarios that can play out. In graph B, if the United States increased the distribution of vaccines to three million vaccines per day, we could reach herd immunity by May. Although this result would be fantastic, and the predicted death rate would reduce by 10,000, it is unlikely because we would have to nearly double our vaccine outtake.  In graph C, if restrictions were ended in April, the United States could reach herd immunity by June. Despite heard immunity being reached faster, we risk losing 70,000 more people without public precautions. This makes me wonder if we will wait until after herd immunity to end restrictions. Graph D represents predicted herd immunity with the added factor of disease variants. Diseases constantly evolve, so we can never be 100% accurate. I feel like a lot of people do not take the virus serious enough to have precautions and everyone get the vaccine. for example in Florida, Georgia, Mississippi, California and more states have lifted their mask mandate and increase to 100% capacity in public places. I wonder how many variants there are out right now that the vaccine will not take care of. I also wonder how the death toll will look after most of us have the vaccine compared to how the death toll looks now considering the vaccines aren't almost fully immune to the variants.

It seems that the best case scenario is graph B, reaching the herd immunity threshold by May. However, this models were created with the idea that vaccines will get us inmune indefinitely, which we still don't know, it's too soon to know how well these vaccines would work, or what its side effects would be. 
On the other hand, these models take for granted that people will follow public precautions, and reality has shown us that it's no so realistic.

Even with easing some restrictions, we could reach herd immunity by June, but it means a lot more people will die. Lastly, by increasing the vaccine rollout from 1.7 million to 3 million shots per day, we could prevent 10,000 deaths. Our group wondered many things from these graphs, such as will the number of deaths start to decrease as many people are starting to get the vaccine. In addition, we wondered if our country increases the supply of vaccines, how would this affect us financially, and can we distribute more vaccines. The impact that this topic has on our community is that we have been dealing with COVID-19 for a year now and having herd immunity would be a big step into getting things back to normal. What??s going on in this graph? Write a catchy headline that captures the graph??s main idea.

"It is a Marathon, Not a Sprint!" This methodology is how we should treat the virus; attack it constantly, but not hold back until the finish.

After studying these graphs, it??s apparent that there's no situation where deaths are completely preventable; they're going to occur regardless of the path we take. That being said, at first glance, Graph B seems to provide the best course of action. It shows that we could reach herd immunity by May, the earliest of all the predicted months, and estimates the least amount of potential deaths (~90,000). However, looking closer at this graph, I wonder at its probability/reality. It says in order to achieve these results, we would have to increase the supply of vaccines to 3 million per day, immediately. That??s nearly double what our current supply is (1.7 M), something that seems difficult to achieve promptly. As far as the impact these graphs and their trajectories have on my community and me, I??d say that Graph A, our current proceedings, seems most beneficial and would be the one I??d encourage us to stick with. I know everyone is anxious for things to return to normal, believe me, I am too, but when weighing the different aspects of each respective graph (timeframe, amount of potential deaths, the feasibility of actions), Graph A seems to provide the best balance. Compared to Graphs C and D, it has fewer deaths while also seeming more plausible than Graph B. The expected herd immunity of Graph A is reached in July, just like Graph D, but predicts fewer deaths than that graph.

The herd immunity threshold could also be reached by May. The largest amount of deaths would occur if we follow Graph D, and continue with the current vaccine supply and more contagious variants emerge. We wonder what prediction will end up being right? We wonder if it is possible to reach herd immunity before vaccine immunity? We also wonder if it is possible for scientists to produce more doses of the vaccine? Also, if people choose not to get the vaccine will that affect the predicted results? This graph impacts us because it shows us in multiple scenarios, when COVID will stop affecting our life so much. It also shows us how if we keep doing simple things like wearing a mask and social distancing, then we will have less deaths caused by COVID.

We also know there are also definitions provided below the graphs to clarify some of the information given. Also, graphs A, B, and D both show situations with public precautions included, while graph C has lifted restrictions. Lastly, graph D shows us that even with our current vaccine distribution, double the amount of people could die if there are contagious variants of the virus. We wonder why the immunity increases so slowly although more people are getting the vaccine. We also wonder why don't we follow some of these graphs and increase the number of people getting vaccinated. We also think which graph will look like what our future will be. Lastly, we wonder if communities see these graphs will they be more likely to keep restrictions high or continue to loosen up. Ultimately, these graphs have a great impact on our community because the COVID-19 virus affects our daily lives, and we have to take precautions to avoid catching the virus. If communities ease up on restrictions, like in graph C, many more people could be harmed even if we continue to distribute vaccines at the current rate and there are no variants. comment:
The graphs shown are showing the time it will take to herd immunity for the Coronavirus in the US. Herd Immunity means 70% ?C 90% of people are immune to the virus, whether through getting vaccinated or becoming infected and creating a natural immunity. Descriptions of what each graph is showing: 
Graph A: Current supply of vaccinations and public precautions
Graph B: Increasing the vaccine supply and maintaining public precautions
Graph C: Maintaining the vaccine supply with lifting some public precautions in the spring
Graph D: Maintaining vaccine supply and public precautions, but experiencing contagious variants 
All four of these graphs present different situations in which herd immunity is speculated to reach the 70%-90% mark. 
Graph B has the ??most effective?? situation. This scenario is upping the vaccine distribution count to 3 million shots per day instead of the 1.7 million in Graphs A, C, and D. It has the fewest deaths, 90,000, out of all four graphs. This graph also shows that the herd of immunity would most likely be reached by May. Graph D on the other hand is the ??least effective?? out of the four graphs. This scenario is saying that a more contagious variant will spread faster, therefore upping the herd of immunity. This graph is predicting the most deaths, 200,000, compared to the lower death toll of graphs A, B, and C. This graph is foreseeing the herd of immunity to be reached by July. I feel that a catchy title could be, "Herd Immunity: Now or Never?"

Welcome to Wednesday's moderation of ??What??s Going On in This Graph???  

Today??s graphs show the results of a model that estimates when the U.S. will obtain herd immunity from the coronavirus.  (Herd immunity occurs when enough people become immunity to a disease to make its spread unlikely.  This is a result of vaccinations and natural infection.)   Here are graphs for four situations:  under current conditions, with increased supply of vaccines, with relaxing social distancing, and with more contagious variant spreads. 

From 9 am ?C 2 pm E.T. today, share with us your responses online to these three questions -- "What do you notice?",  "What do you wonder?", and ??What impact does this topic have on you and your community???

Plus, please share with us a catchy headline that captures the ideas in these graphs. 

By Friday morning, we??ll reveal the article that included these graphs and much more.  We look forward to reading your discoveries.

Note that you can get a link to your response to share with your teacher and classmates by clicking the response box below your response ??Email me when my comment is published.??  

View our archives that link to past releases, organized by topic (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsTopicIndex), 
graph type (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsTypeIndex) and 
Stat Nugget (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsStatNuggetsIndex).  

Keep noticing and wondering.  The next graph on U.S. recent land development will be released by Friday, March 12 with moderation on Wednesday, March 17.

A fork in the road, options on how to deal with covid vaccines

I notice that the four graphs represent four possible ways in which the United States could reach herd immunity. The first graph shows what the future could look like if we continue with life as it is now: 1.7 million vaccinations a day with public precautions (social distancing and mask-wearing). The second graph shows a future in which 3 million vaccinations are given per day. In this possible scenario, we would reach herd immunity by May. The third graph shows what the future would look like if we continue with 1 million vaccinations a day, and then lift the restrictions in April. In this scenario, we would reach herd immunity faster, but with more deaths. The final example shows a future in which a more contagious variant spreads. In this scenario, it would take until July to reach herd immunity and up to 200,000 more people could die from the virus.

I wonder which scenario is most likely. I also wonder if the government plans on increasing their vaccination rates to 3 million shots per day, like in the second graph. I wonder if a more contagious variant has already begun to spread throughout the U.S. Finally, I wonder what exactly herd immunity entails. Does herd immunity mean that the virus vanishes completely?

This impacts my community because vaccinations mean less deaths and a return to normal life in my community. Covid 19 is abundant in my city and increased vaccination rates would help us all greatly.

1). When first observing the following graphic, there is a trend of Southern states facing greater vaccination barriers, all of which are rooted in health care problems or generalized poverty. Another trend that was noticeable in the graph is the lack of distinction between rural and urban. Personally, I would like to know the environment in which these problems are present. For example, is a metropolis not compensating for the oversaturated urban areas or are rural areas not reaching their full vaccination? Furthermore, how are limitations assessed in the data set used? Could there be other factors not represented by the following infographic like inefficient systems of administration blocking citizens from getting their vaccines? 
2). NY is a heavily populated state so it can be assumed that the waves of vaccination might take a bit longer. However, from family and friends, I've heard various situations with regards to the barriers being presented. Some do feel that communication was sparse while others got the vaccine with ease. I wonder if political ideals play into which states have lower or higher levels of concern, as well as which states have more barriers. Seeing as southern states (relatively more conservative states) have high levels of concern whereas more liberal states (OR, CA, WA, NY, etc) have lower levels of concern and fewer barriers. Living in Oregon, it looks like our heaviest barriers are low health care resources, historic undervaccination, and irregular medical care. Knowing many people who cannot afford health care or doctors visits, this makes sense to me. I am worried for our community, especially our high houseless population, who are more at risk due to the inability to use healthcare resources. I also know several immunocompromised people who are banking on herd immunity to save them, but when so many people are historically unvaccinated this may not be a safe bet.

This graph divides the United States of America into fifty states into bubbles, each bubble has five data points that ultimately represent the risk levels of Covid-19 and any resistance to the use of vaccine within each state. The group noticed a few things about this graph, for one we noticed that the more vaccine-hesitant and higher risk areas were generally clustered in the southern states. In contrast, the east, especially Mssacushets and Connecticut, have the lowest risks of Covid-19 and the most vaccine usage across the country. Our group still remains curious about the accuracy of this graph. We wonder how all this data was collected and about the reliability of the results. We believe that this graph impacts the spread and containment of the coronavirus. Which affects our path back to normality. It appears to affect me and my community because the health care resources are very low in Minnesota and that's where we all live.

user_display_name: Grace U, Kaitlin B, Evan D, Brian S
comment:
Kaitlin Bryhn, Grace Urban, Evan Divine, and Brian Samuel

The data presented in these graphs led to severing findings that our group noticed. The first thing we found was that the East coast has relatively low concern levels for vaccination barriers. However, New York, Pennsylvania, and Rhode Island share similar concerns for social economic barriers. We also noticed that there are more vaccination barriers in the Southern states. Our own state of Minnesota has a relatively low level of concern. We also wondered why there is such a great divide between the North and the South in vaccination barriers? Could this be a result of certain regions being prioritized for vaccination over other states and what impact does that have on vaccination barriers? Access to vaccinations plays a major role in ensuring that the entire community can be healthy and safe amidst this pandemic. In Minnesota, vaccination access is much better than many other states, although the greatest barrier is low health care resources. Depending on which state you live in, this will affect the role the government plays in mandating policies to curb the spread and distribute vaccinations. Lastly, if your state has a low level of concern, restrictions might be limited and the community might open up sooner. We would title this article, ??America??s grasp on vaccines: Vaccination barriers and their fingerprints.??

In looking at this graph, it is obvious that the states located on the southern part of the US have more vaccination barriers than the northern part of the US. I also notice that the western part of the United also has more coronavirus vaccination barriers as well. I wonder why the northeast and northwest of the US have the least amount of vaccination barriers. I also wonder why poor health care access will limit the amount of vaccines given as vaccine doses purchased with taxpayer dollars are free, there could just be an administering fee. If we are trying to create a herd immunity, shouldn't places that are low income be offered free vaccines if the actual dosage is free to the person administering it? This does not directly impact my community but impacts my country because New Jersey has  very low barriers on vaccinations.

The graph depicts the various factors that may contribute to vaccination barriers in each state. As such, a relevant title for this graph may be "What Barriers are Restricting Rapid Vaccination in Your State?" because it is both eye-catching and it reveals the purpose of the graph to the reader without them having to try to understand what information is being presented.

Welcome to Wednesday's moderation of ??What??s Going On in This Graph???  

Today??s radar graphs show the barriers for rapid, widespread vaccination by state and the summarized overall level of concern by state.  If you go to the New York Times article ??What Are the Vaccine Roadblocks Where You Live?, you can enter your county and see the barriers for your community.

From 9 am ?C 2 pm E.T. today, share with us your responses online to these three questions -- "What do you notice?",  "What do you wonder?", and ??What impact does this topic have on you and your community???  

Plus, please share with us a catchy headline that captures the ideas in these graphs. We will publish in Friday??s Reveal some of the on-target and catchiest headlines.

By Friday morning, we??ll reveal the article that included these graphs and much more.  We look forward to reading your discoveries.

Note that you can get a link to your response to share with your teacher and classmates by clicking the response box below your response ??Email me when my comment is published.??

This impacts me because I know people who are frontline workers and essential workers. With limited supply and increasing infection rate, the prioritization of who receives the vaccine is important. While frontline workers have greater exposure and are more likely to catch COVID, cases spread quickly among the general population. Public places, like schools, that are open are also vulnerable, and therefore those with educational jobs can be as susceptible as frontline workers. COVID has affected many families, especially those with members who are essential and frontline workers. Hopefully, with the distribution of vaccines right now, both spread and deaths will be reduced.

This infographic would be very helpful for someone who unsure of what field to go into and what jobs are protected and affected by epidemics and shutdowns. Headline: "Frontline Workers Battle for Vaccine Access"

Welcome to Wednesday's moderation of today??s graph which shows the number of essential and frontline essential workers by occupation.  About 70% of U.S. workers are considered essential, with a subgroup of workers considered frontline essential workers because their jobs cannot be performed from home.

From 9 am ?C 2 pm E.T. today, share with us your responses online to these three questions -- "What do you notice?",  "What do you wonder?", and ??What impact does this topic have on you and your community???

Plus, please share with us a catchy headline that captures the ideas in these graphs. 

By Friday morning, we??ll reveal the article that included this graph and much more.  We look forward to reading your discoveries.

Note that you can get a link to your response to share with your teacher and classmates by clicking the response box below your response ??Email me when my comment is published.??
